The portion after the '#' (the 'fragment') is not sent on HTTP requests, 
and so does not affect what is returned from servers. So from the 
perspective of recording what servers publish under certain URIs, it is 
irrelevant.

Of course, it *is* relevant to interpretation, but that means 
considering the full browser-like context and path by which a document 
was reached. There's enough information to consider this in post-crawl 
analysis -- the source document still has the URI with the '#fragment' 
part -- but Heritrix discards it for its harvesting-centric process.

Because some may want more analysis to occur during harvesting -- for 
example, realistic Javascript execution which *can* consult the 
'#fragment'-part in the location bar -- it would make sense to add some 
support, and I'd welcome a JIRA feature-request for the kind of support 
you need.

It still might not go into the (W)ARC record's main URI field, since 
that is most closely associated with preserving a transcript of the 
network activity, where the '#fragment' does not appear. (From the 
perspective of a (W)ARC, this seems like path-dependent advisory 
metadata to me.)

- Gordon @ IA
